DataElement.preferredName: Colorectal Cancer AJCC Edition 8 Clinical Tumor T Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Extent of the primary colon and rectal carcinoma based on information obtained from the date of cancer diagnosis until the start of definitive treatment, or within four months (whichever is shorter), using AJCC Ed. 8 criteria.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Questionnaire Domain Colorectal Neoplasm Clinical T Category
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A subject domain utilized for the submission of information encompassing and representing data, vocabulary or records related to questionnaire._Relating to the colon and rectum, or to the entire large bowel._A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation.  The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity._One criteria of the TNM staging system. T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion).

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A subject domain utilized for the submission of information encompassing and representing data, vocabulary or records related to questionnaire.

Concepts.definition: A subject domain utilized for the submission of information encompassing and representing data, vocabulary or records related to questionnaire.

Property.preferredDefinition: Relating to the colon and rectum, or to the entire large bowel.:A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.:Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation.  The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity.:One criteria of the TNM staging system. T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion).

Concepts.definition: Relating to the colon and rectum, or to the entire large bowel.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.
Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation.  The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity.
One criteria of the TNM staging system. T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion).

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: An organizational header for concepts representing mostly abstract entities.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Created for CDSIC aligned NCI Standard CRFs. wz

ValueDomain.preferredName: Colorectal Carcinoma American Joint Committee on Cancer Edition 8 T Category
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A finding about one or more characteristics of colorectal cancer, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v8 classification system. Adenocarcinomas, high-grade neuroendocrine carcinomas, and squamous cell carcinomas of the colon and rectum are covered by this staging system. Appendiceal carcinomas, anal carcinomas, and well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumors (carcinoids) are not covered by this staging system. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)_A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications._One criteria of the TNM staging system. T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion)._A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Colorectal Cancer pT4b TNM Finding v8

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Colorectal Cancer pT4b TNM Finding v8
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Colorectal cancer with tumor directly invading or adhering to adjacent organs or structures. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Colorectal Cancer pT4b TNM Finding v8
Concepts.definition: Colorectal cancer with tumor directly invading or adhering to adjacent organs or structures. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Colorectal Cancer pT4a TNM Finding v8

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Colorectal Cancer pT4a TNM Finding v8
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Colorectal cancer with tumor invading through the visceral peritoneum (including gross perforation of the bowel through tumor and continuous invasion of tumor through areas of inflammation to the surface of the visceral peritoneum). (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Colorectal Cancer pT4a TNM Finding v8
Concepts.definition: Colorectal cancer with tumor invading through the visceral peritoneum (including gross perforation of the bowel through tumor and continuous invasion of tumor through areas of inflammation to the surface of the visceral peritoneum). (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Colorectal Cancer pT4 TNM Finding v8

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Colorectal Cancer pT4 TNM Finding v8
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Colorectal cancer with tumor invading the visceral peritoneum or invading or adhering to adjacent organ or structure. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Colorectal Cancer pT4 TNM Finding v8
Concepts.definition: Colorectal cancer with tumor invading the visceral peritoneum or invading or adhering to adjacent organ or structure. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Colorectal Cancer pT2 TNM Finding v8

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Colorectal Cancer pT2 TNM Finding v8
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Colorectal cancer with tumor invading the muscularis propria. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Colorectal Cancer pT2 TNM Finding v8
Concepts.definition: Colorectal cancer with tumor invading the muscularis propria. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Colorectal Cancer pT3 TNM Finding v8

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Colorectal Cancer pT3 TNM Finding v8
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Colorectal cancer with tumor invading through the muscularis propria into pericolorectal tissues. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Colorectal Cancer pT3 TNM Finding v8
Concepts.definition: Colorectal cancer with tumor invading through the muscularis propria into pericolorectal tissues. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Colorectal Cancer pT1 TNM Finding v8

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Colorectal Cancer pT1 TNM Finding v8
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Colorectal cancer with tumor invading the submucosa (through the muscularis mucosa but not into the muscularis propria). (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Colorectal Cancer pT1 TNM Finding v8
Concepts.definition: Colorectal cancer with tumor invading the submucosa (through the muscularis mucosa but not into the muscularis propria). (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Colorectal Cancer pTis TNM Finding v8

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Colorectal Cancer pTis TNM Finding v8
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Colorectal cancer with a finding of carcinoma in situ, intramucosal carcinoma (involvement of lamina propria with no extension through muscularis mucosae). (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Colorectal Cancer pTis TNM Finding v8
Concepts.definition: Colorectal cancer with a finding of carcinoma in situ, intramucosal carcinoma (involvement of lamina propria with no extension through muscularis mucosae). (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Colorectal Cancer pT0 TNM Finding v8

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Colorectal Cancer pT0 TNM Finding v8
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Colorectal cancer with no evidence of primary tumor. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Colorectal Cancer pT0 TNM Finding v8
Concepts.definition: Colorectal cancer with no evidence of primary tumor. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Colorectal Cancer pTX TNM Finding v8

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Colorectal Cancer pTX TNM Finding v8
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Colorectal cancer in which the primary tumor cannot be assessed. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Colorectal Cancer pTX TNM Finding v8
Concepts.definition: Colorectal cancer in which the primary tumor cannot be assessed. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).
